question: In order to be able to penetrate cloud, a primary radar signal must have?
explanation:
Primary radar systems detect targets by transmitting an electromagnetic wave into the
target area, then detecting the waves that are reflected from the targets. The direction
from which the returning waves approach the radar antenna indicates the bearing of the
target and the time between the transmission of the wave and the arrival of the returning
echo is used to determine the range of the target. This means primary radar is entirely
dependent upon the ability of targets to reflect the electromagnetic waves.

The degree to which electromagnetic waves are reflected by an object is largely
determined by the size of the object relative to the wavelength of the wave. If the object
size is very close to the wavelength this will cause most of the wave energy to be
reflected. This would give very good returns, but would prevent the wave from moving
on to detect more distant objects. So a wavelength close to the size of water droplets in
clouds, would give very good indications of the clouds, but would be unable to penetrate
them. If the object size is much smaller than the wavelength this will permit the wave to
pass the object with very little energy being reflected. This would permit the majority of
the wave to continue to move forward to detect more distance larger objects. So in order
to penetrate cloud, a primary radar signal must have a long wavelength.
subject: Radio Navigation
